title: Crafting a compelling product vision | Ebi Atawodi (YouTube, Netflix, Uber)
key_insights: A good product vision must be lofty yet realistic, devoid of today's technical limitations, and grounded in clear user problems
Product management craft boils down to two core elements: clarity (understanding problems) and conviction (having a clear vision of solutions)
Use the 'Once upon a time' storytelling framework to communicate vision: describe current state, problem, solution, and resulting world state
Maintain a living document of 'top 10 things you should know' - key problems your users face, updated quarterly
Company culture directly influences how products are built - from Uber's aggressive autonomy to Netflix's structured decision-making to Google's microcultures
Evangelize vision in three concentric circles: core team first, then stakeholders, then leadership
Use concrete artifacts like mock headlines, app store screenshots, or sketches to make vision tangible and memorable
Build relationships with engineering partners by knowing personal details like birthdays and career aspirations

guest_background.current_role: Director of Product Management at YouTube (Creator Experience)

topics_discussed: Four elements of effective product vision
Three methods for communicating vision (Mad Libs, press articles, mockups)
Three-step vision development process (empathize, create, evangelize)
Top 10 problems framework for user research
Three-day strategy workshop structure (insights, strategy, big rocks)
Clarity and conviction as core PM skills
Cultural differences between Uber, Netflix, and Google
How company culture shapes product development
Vulnerability and love vs. being liked in leadership
Career transition advice for aspiring PMs

summary: Ebi Atawodi shares highly tactical frameworks for developing and communicating product vision, emphasizing the importance of clarity and conviction in product management. She provides concrete tools like the 'Once upon a time' storytelling method and demonstrates how company culture directly influences product development through her experiences at Uber, Netflix, and Google.
